Mount Vernon, Iowa
                                                                                     May 22, 1936

Mr. Edward Eberstadt
55 West 42nd Street
New York City
Dear Sir:

            I have the pamphlet Left by the Indians

by Emeline L. Fuller, for which you have advertised
in the Mt. Vernon Hawk-Eye [underline] of May 21st. In fact
it was written by my father. When I was a little
girl, there were many copies in our house, but they
were all destroyed. The copy I have I secured in
1927 from a box of old photographs of my uncle's
in Yakima, Washington where I was visiting. The
4 by 5 booklet in my possession is damaged to the
extent that the light blue paper cover is gone and also
the page on which my father wrote some remarks
and signed his name.

            Mr. Mc Cutcheon, in whose paper you

advertised, examined the booklet and said that it shows
an excellent job of printing. I do not desire, however,
to part with it; so perhaps you will not be interested
further. If there is any material in it in which you are
interested, perhaps I could be of service to you without
letting the brochure out of my hands.

              I doubt very much if there is another copy in

existence. My father, James Hughes, was an evangelist
at the time he wrote it, and in one of the towns Mrs.
Emeline Fuller attended his meetings. Sympathetic friends
about [strike] told him about Mrs. Fuller's horrible experiences
with Indians when she went West as a child. My
father met her, urged her to let him write an account
of her stay. She was a frail, sad, timid little woman
and consented reluctantly. My father thought perhaps
the booklets could be sold to people in his meetings
in the various towns and she could be helped financially.
My mother, who is seventy-five years old and who saw
your advertisement in our local paper, has told me what
I have written to you. She says that Mrs. Fuller
visited us for several days in the old house in which
we still live, but she has forgotten in which one of

these midwestern states  it was that my father ran 
across her.

         The booklet is not at all literary, but I am quite

sure it is what it aimed to be; that is, a truthful
account of Mrs. Fuller's experiences.

          This is perhaps a much longer reply than is

necessary, but I think the personal side may excuse
what is profuse.

                      Very truly yours,
                       (Miss) Geraldine Hughes
